æ¯”èµ›é“¾æ¥ A[Codeforces 1920A] Satisfying Constraints.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;int n, a[N];void solve(){ n = read(); int max = 1e9 + 5, min = 0; std::set<int> s; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { int opt = read(), x = read(); if (opt == 1) min = std::max(min, x); else if (opt == 2) max = std::min(max, x); else s.insert(x); } int ans = max - min + 1; for (auto x : s) if (min <= x and x <= max) ans --; ans = std::max(ans, 0); printf("%d
", ans);}int main(){ // freopen("A.in", "r", stdin); for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Bç»™å®šä¸€ä¸ªå…¨éƒ½æ˜¯æ­£æ•´æ•°çš„æ•°ç»„ï¼ŒA ç©å®¶å¯ä»¥å…ˆç§»å»æœ€å¤š k ä¸ªå…ƒç´ ï¼Œéšå B ç©å®¶å¯ä»¥æœ€å¤šç»™ x ä¸ªå…ƒç´ åŠ ä¸Šè´Ÿå·ã€‚A å¸Œæœ›æœ€å¤§åŒ–æ•°ç»„å…ƒç´ ä¹‹å’Œï¼Œè€Œ B å¸Œæœ›æœ€å°åŒ–æ•°ç»„å…ƒç´ ä¹‹å’Œã€‚å¦‚æœåŒæ–¹éƒ½ä»¥æœ€ä¼˜æ–¹å¼è¿›è¡Œæ¸¸æˆï¼Œæ±‚æ¸¸æˆç»“æŸåæ•°ç»„å…ƒç´ çš„æ€»å’Œã€‚ n <= 2e5 B çš„å†³ç­–è‚¯å®šæ˜¯ç»™æœ€å¤§çš„å‡ ä¸ªéƒ½åŠ ä¸Šè´Ÿå·ã€‚A è¦åˆ è‚¯å®šæ˜¯åˆ å¤§çš„ï¼Œæšä¸¾å³å¯ [Codeforces 1920B] Summation Game.cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;int n, k, x, a[N], pre[N];void solve(){ n = read(), k = read(), x = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); std::sort(a + 1, a + 1 + n, [](int a, int b){return a > b;}); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) pre[i] = pre[i - 1] + a[i]; int ans = -1e9 + 5; for (int i = 0; i <= k; i++) { int p = std::min(i + x, n); ans = std::max(ans, -(pre[p] - pre[i]) + pre[n] - pre[p]); } printf("%d
", ans);}int main(){ // freopen("A.in", "r", stdin); for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} CæŠŠæ•°ç»„åˆ‡æˆæ­£å¥½ k å—ï¼Œç„¶åæŠŠæ¯ä¸ªæ•°éƒ½ mod mï¼Œé—®ä½ æœ‰å¤šå°‘ä¸ª kï¼Œå­˜åœ¨ m ä½¿å¾— mod m åæ¯ä¸€å—éƒ½ç›¸åŒ ä¸¤ä¸ªæ•°å¦‚æœåœ¨æ¨¡æ„ä¹‰ä¸‹ç›¸ç­‰ï¼Œé‚£ä»–ä»¬çš„å·®å¿…ç„¶åœ¨æ¨¡æ„ä¹‰ä¸‹ä¸º 0ã€‚å¯¹è¿™äº›å·®æ±‚ gcd å³å¯ check æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨ mã€‚ [Codeforces 1920C] Partitioning the Array.cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748495051525354#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>#include <numeric>int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 2e5 + 5;int n, a[N], ans;void judge(int k){ int cnt = 0, x = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= k; i++) for (int j = i + k; j <= n; j += k) { int val = abs(a[j] - a[j - k]); if (!val) continue; if (!x) x = val, cnt = 1; else x = std::gcd(x, val); } if (x >= 2 or cnt == 0) ans++;}void solve(){ n = read(), ans = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); for (int i = 1; i * i <= n; i++) if (n % i == 0) { judge(n / i); if (n / i != i) judge(i); } printf("%d
", ans);}int main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("C.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Dç»™å®šä¸€ä¸ªç©ºæ•°ç»„ï¼Œä¸¤ç§æ“ä½œï¼Œä¸€ç§æ˜¯æœ«å°¾ push è¿›å»ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°ï¼Œä¸€ç§æ˜¯æŠŠè‡ªå·±å¤åˆ¶ x æ¬¡ï¼Œpush åˆ°æœ«å°¾ å¤šæ¬¡è¯¢é—®ï¼ŒæŸ¥è¯¢ä»»æ„ä½ç½® èµ›æ—¶å˜´å·´ç§’äº†ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä¸ä¼šå®ç°ã€‚åšæ³•æ˜¯ä¸æ–­å–æ¨¡ï¼Œå¾€å‰è·³ã€‚ è®°å½•æ¯ä¸€æ¬¡æ“ä½œåæ•°ç»„çš„é•¿åº¦å’Œæ•°ç»„æœ«å°¾çš„æ•°çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚å¯¹äºä¸€ä¸ªè¯¢é—®ï¼Œä¸æ–­äºŒåˆ†å–æ¨¡å³å¯ [Codeforces 1920D] Array Repetition.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344454647484950515253545556575859606162#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>#define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;int las[N], dp[N];void solve(){ int n = read(), q = read(); for (int i = 0; i <= n; i++) las[i] = dp[i] = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { int opt = read(), x = read(); if (opt == 1) las[i] = x, dp[i] = dp[i - 1] + 1; else las[i] = las[i - 1], dp[i] = (x + 1) > 2e18 / dp[i - 1] ? (long long)2e18 : dp[i - 1] * (x + 1); } for (int k; q--; ) { k = read(); while (1) { int pos = std::lower_bound(dp + 1, dp + 1 + n, k) - dp; if (dp[pos] == k) { std::cout << las[pos] << ' '; break; } if (k % dp[pos - 1] == 0) { std::cout << las[pos - 1] << ' '; break; } k %= dp[pos - 1]; } } puts("");}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} E>folded1

æ¯”èµ›é“¾æ¥ A[Codeforces 1925A] We Got Everything Covered!.cpp >folded12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;int n, a[N];void solve(){ int n = read(), k = read(); for (int i = 0, j = 1; j <= n * k; j++, i = (i + 1) % k) printf("%c", 'a' + i); puts("");}int main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} B[Codeforces 1925B] A Balanced Problemset?.cpp >folded12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>// #define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 3e5 + 5;int n, a[N];int b[N];void solve(){ int x = read(), n = read(), ans = 1; for (int i = 1; i * i <= x; i++) if (x % i == 0) { if (n <= x / i) ans = std::max(ans, i); if (n <= i) ans = std::max(ans, x / i); } std::cout << ans << '
';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("B.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Cåœ¨ç­”æ¡ˆçš„æ„é€ ä¸Šæœ‰ä¸€äº›å°ç»†èŠ‚å®¹æ˜“è¢«å‘ å‰é¢çš„ä¸èƒ½ä¹±å¡« [Codeforces 1925C] Did We Get Everything Covered?.cpp >folded12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940414243444546474849#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}bool buk[26];void solve(){ int n = read(), k = read(), m = read(); std::string s, ans; std::cin >> s; int cnt = 0, tot = 0; memset(buk, 0, sizeof buk); for (auto ch : s) { if (ans.size() == n) break; cnt += !buk[ch - 'a'], buk[ch - 'a'] = 1; if (cnt == k) cnt = 0, ans += ch, memset(buk, 0, sizeof buk); } if (ans.size() == n) puts("YES"); else { puts("NO"); for (int i = 0; i < k; i++) if (!buk[i]) while (ans.size() < n) ans += char(i + 'a'); std::cout << ans << '
'; }}int main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("C.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Då‡ºé¢˜äººå‡ºçš„ä»€ä¹ˆç˜ è–„é¢˜é¢ best sol [Codeforces 1925D] Good Trip.cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>#define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int P = 1e9 + 7;int pow(int x, int k, int res = 1){ for (x = (x + P) % P; k; k >>= 1, x = x * x % P) if (k & 1) res = res * x % P; return res;}void solve(){ int n = read(), m = read(), k = read(); int sum = 0, ans = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= m; i++) read(), read(), sum = (sum + read()) % P; int all = pow(n * (n - 1) / 2, P - 2), p = m * all % P; for (int i = 1; i <= k; i++) ans = (ans + sum * all) % P, sum = (sum + p) % P; std::cout << ans << '
';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} E>folded1

æ¯”èµ›é“¾æ¥ A[Codeforces 1918A] Brick Wall.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;int n, a[N];void solve(){ int n = read(), m = read(); printf("%d
", n * (m / 2));}int main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} B[Codeforces 1918B] Minimize Inversions.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344454647#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>// #define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 3e5 + 5;int n;struct Node{ int x, y; bool friend operator < (Node a, Node b) { return a.x + a.y < b.x + b.y; }} a[N];void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i].x = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i].y = read(); std::sort(a + 1, a + 1 + n); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) printf("%d ", a[i].x); puts(""); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) printf("%d ", a[i].y); puts("");}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("B.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} CæŒ‰ä½è´ªå¿ƒå³å¯ æœ‰ä¸ªå°å‘æ˜¯ä»ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª 1-0 çš„ä¸‹ä¸€ä½å¼€å§‹æ“ä½œ [Codeforces 1918C] XOR-distance.cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>#define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}void solve(){ int a = read(), b = read(), r = read(); int k = 0, ans = 0; if (a < b) std::swap(a, b); for (int i = 63; i >= 0; i--) if (((a >> i) & 1LL) == 1 and ((b >> i) & 1LL) == 0) { k = i; break; } // printf("k : %lld
", k); for (int i = k - 1; i >= 0; i--) { int x = (a >> i) & 1LL, y = (b >> i) & 1LL; if (x == 1 and y == 0) { if (ans + (1LL << i) <= r) ans += 1LL << i; } } // printf("[%lld]
", ans); int x = a ^ ans; int y = b ^ ans; printf("%lld
", x - y);}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("C.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Dä¸€çœ¼äºŒåˆ†ï¼Œèµ›æ—¶ä¸ä¼š judgeã€‚ä¸ä¼šå¤„ç†æ–­ç‚¹çš„å’Œã€‚ ä¸€ä¸ªå¸¸è§çš„å¤„ç†æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯æŠŠæ–­ç‚¹çš„å’Œæ”¾åˆ° dp æ•°ç»„é‡Œé¢ç»´æŠ¤ï¼Œè½¬ç§»çš„æ—¶å€™ä»è·ç¦»å°äºé™åˆ¶çš„åœ°æ–¹è½¬ç§»å³å¯ å¯ä»¥è½¬ç§»çš„èŒƒå›´æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ»‘åŠ¨çª—å£ $$f_i = a_i + \min_{s_{i - 1} - s_j \leq lim}{f_j}$$ [Codeforces 1918D] Blocking Elements.cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748495051525354#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>#define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;const int INF = 1LL << 60;int n, a[N], sum[N], q[N], f[N];bool judge(int lim){ int h = 1, t = 0; q[++t] = 0; for (int i = 0; i <= n + 1; i++) f[i] = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n + 1; i++) { for (; h <= t and sum[i - 1] - sum[q[h]] > lim; h++); f[i] = a[i] + f[q[h]]; for (; h <= t and f[i] <= f[q[t]]; t--); q[++t] = i; } return f[n + 1] <= lim;}void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); a[n + 1] = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) sum[i] = sum[i - 1] + a[i]; int ans = 0; for (int L = 1, R = sum[n], mid; L <= R; ) if (judge(mid = (L + R) >> 1)) ans = mid, R = mid - 1; else L = mid + 1; std::cout << ans << '
';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} E>folded1

æ¯”èµ›é“¾æ¥ A[Codeforces 1928A] Rectangle Cutting.cpp >folded12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940414243#include <bits/stdc++.h>#define int long long#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;const int INF = 1LL << 60;int n, a[N];void solve(){ int a = read(), b = read(); if (a < b) std::swap(a, b); if (a % 2 == 0) { // a / 2, b * 2 int c = a / 2, d = b * 2; if (c < d) std::swap(c, d); if (a != c or b != d) return puts("YES"), void(); } if (b % 2 == 0) { int c = b / 2, d = a * 2; if (c < d) std::swap(c, d); if (a != c or b != d) return puts("YES"), void(); } puts("NO");}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Bå»é‡ä»¥ååœ¨æ•°è½´ä¸Šæ»‘åŠ¨çª—å£ [Codeforces 1928B] Equalize.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738#include <bits/stdc++.h>#define int long long#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;const int INF = 1LL << 60;int n, a[N];void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); std::sort(a + 1, a + 1 + n); int m = std::unique(a + 1, a + 1 + n) - a - 1, ans = 1; for (int i = 1; i <= m; i++) { int res = i; for (int L = i, R = m, mid; L <= R;) if (a[mid = (L + R) / 2] - a[i] < n) res = mid, L = mid + 1; else R = mid - 1; ans = std::max(ans, res - i + 1); } printf("%d
", ans);}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("B.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Cç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‡ºç°çš„ä½ç½®æ˜¯ x å’Œ 2k - xï¼Œå¾ªç¯èŠ‚é•¿åº¦æ˜¯ 2k - 2 è§£æ–¹ç¨‹ $n \equiv x \pmod{2k - 2}$ å’Œ $n \equiv {2k - x} \pmod{2k - 2}$ ç­‰ä»·äº $n - x \equiv 0 \pmod{2k - 2}$ å’Œ $n + x - 2 \equiv 0 \pmod{2k - 2}$ æšä¸¾å› æ•°å³å¯ [Codeforces 1928C] Physical Education Lesson.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738#include <bits/stdc++.h>// #define int long long#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;int n, x, kmax, a, b;std::set<int> S;void push(int y){ if (y % 2 != 0) return; int k = (y + 2) / 2; if (std::max(2, x) <= k and k <= kmax) S.insert(k);}void solve(){ n = read(), x = read(), S.clear(); kmax = (n + x) / 2, a = n - x, b = n + x - 2; for (int i = 1; i * i <= a; i++) if (a % i == 0) push(i), push(a / i); for (int i = 1; i * i <= b; i++) if (b % i == 0) push(i), push(b / i); printf("%d

-x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;const int INF = 1e18;int n, m, a[N];void solve(){ n = read(), m = read(); vector<int> c(n + 1); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) c[i] = read(); vector<vector<int>> a(n + 1, vector<int>(m + 1)); vector<vector<pii>> b(m + 1); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++) a[i][j] = read(), b[j].pb({a[i][j], i}); vector<vector<int>> rk(n + 1, vector<int>(m + 1)); vector<vector<int>> dec(n + 1, vector<int>(m + 1)); for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++) { std::sort(b[j].begin(), b[j].end()); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { auto [x, id] = b[j][i]; rk[id][j] = i + 1; dec[i + 1][j] = id; } } int ans = INF; vector<int> vis(n + 1, 0); vector<vector<int>> dist(n + 1, vector<int>(m + 1, INF)); std::priority_queue<tuu, vector<tuu>, std::greater<tuu>> Q; vis[1] = 1; for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++) dist[1][j] = 0, Q.push({dist[1][j], 1, j}); while (!Q.empty()) { auto [w, x, t] = Q.top(); Q.pop(); // cout << w << x << t << '
'; if (dist[x][t] < w) continue; if (x == n) ans = std::min(ans, w + c[n]); if (rk[x][t] < n) { int z = dec[rk[x][t] + 1][t]; if (w < dist[z][t]) dist[z][t] = w, Q.push({dist[z][t], z, t}); } if (rk[x][t] > 1) { int z = dec[rk[x][t] - 1][t]; if (w + a[x][t] - a[z][t] < dist[z][t]) dist[z][t] = w + a[x][t] - a[z][t], Q.push({dist[z][t], z, t}); } if (!vis[x]) { vis[x] = 1; for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++) if (w + c[x] < dist[x][j]) dist[x][j] = w + c[x], Q.push({dist[x][j], x, j}); } } cout << ans << '
';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("E.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;}

'; break; } }}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("C.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} D A string $t$ is said to be $k$-good if there exists at least one substring$^\dagger$ of length $k$ which is not a palindrome$^\ddagger$. -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;// const int INF = 1e18;int n, m, a[N];std::vector<int> manacher(string s){ string t = "#"; for (auto ch : s) t += ch, t += '#'; int n = t.size(); vector<int> r(n); for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < n; i++) { if (2 * j - i >= 0 and j + r[j] > i) r[i] = std::min(r[2 * j - i], j + r[j] - i); while (i - r[i] >= 0 and i + r[i] < n and t[i - r[i]] == t[i + r[i]]) r[i]++; if (i + r[i] > j + r[j]) j = i; } return r;}void solve(){ n = read(), m = read(); string s; cin >> s; vector<int> f1(n), f2(n); for (int i = n - 1; ~i; i--) f1[i] = i + 1 < n and s[i] == s[i + 1] ? f1[i + 1] : i, f2[i] = i + 2 < n and s[i] == s[i + 2] ? f2[i + 2] : i; auto rad = manacher(s); for (int l, r; m--; ) { l = read() - 1, r = read() - 1; int ans = 0, len = r - l + 1; if (f1[l] < r) { // å­˜åœ¨å¶æ•° k int m = (len - 1) - (len - 1) % 2; ans += (m + 2) * (m / 2) / 2; } if (f2[l] + 1 < r or f2[l + 1] + 1 < r) { // å­˜åœ¨å¥‡æ•° k int m = len - 1 - len % 2; ans += (m + 3) * ((m - 1) / 2) / 2; } if (rad[l + r + 1] < len) ans += len; cout << ans << '
'; }}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} E ç»™ä½ ä¸€æ£µæ ‘ï¼Œæ ‘ä¸Šæœ‰ $n$ ä¸ªé¡¶ç‚¹ï¼Œç¼–å·ä¸º $1, 2, \ldots, n$ ã€‚æœ€åˆï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰é¡¶ç‚¹éƒ½è¢«æ¶‚æˆç™½è‰²ã€‚ æ‚¨å¯ä»¥æ‰§è¡Œä»¥ä¸‹ä¸¤æ­¥æ“ä½œï¼š é€‰æ‹©é¡¶ç‚¹ $v$ ( $1 \leq v \leq n$ ) å’Œè·ç¦» $d$ ( $0 \leq d \leq n-1$ )ã€‚ å¯¹äºæ‰€æœ‰é¡¶ç‚¹ $u$ ( $1 \leq u \leq n$ ) ä¸” $	ext{dist}^\dagger(u,v)=d$ çš„é¡¶ç‚¹ï¼Œå°† $u$ ç€è‰²ä¸ºé»‘è‰²ã€‚æ„é€ ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œåºåˆ—ï¼Œç”¨å°½å¯èƒ½å°‘çš„æ“ä½œæ¬¡æ•°å°†æ ‘ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰èŠ‚ç‚¹æ¶‚æˆé»‘è‰²ã€‚å¯ä»¥è¯æ˜ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ€»æ˜¯å¯ä»¥ç”¨æœ€å¤š $n$ æ¬¡çš„æ“ä½œæ¥å®ç°è¿™ä¸€ç›®çš„ã€‚ è€ƒè™‘ä¸€æ¡é“¾ä¸Šçš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œåˆ†å¥‡å¶è®¨è®ºï¼Œæœ€ä¼˜çš„æ–¹æ³•ä¸€å®šæ˜¯ä»ä¸­å¿ƒå¼€å§‹ï¼Œå‘ä¸¤è¾¹æ‹“å±• æ ‘ä¸Šå‘¢ï¼Ÿç”¨ç›´å¾„å³å¯ [Codeforces 1944E] Tree Compass.cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748495051525354555657585960616263646566676869#include <bits/stdc++.h>// #define int long longusing pii = std::pair<int, int>;using tuu = std::tuple<int, int, int>;#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string, std::vector;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;// const int INF = 1e18;int n, m, a[N];void solve(){ n = read(); vector<vector<int>> g(n); for (int i = 1, u, v; i < n; i++) u = read() - 1, v = read() - 1, g[u].pb(v), g[v].pb(u); vector<int> fa(n); auto find = [&](int rt) { vector<int> dep(n, -1); fa[rt] = -1, dep[rt] = 0; std::queue<int> Q; Q.push(rt); for (int u; !Q.empty(); ) { u = Q.front(); Q.pop(); for (auto v : g[u]) if (dep[v] == -1) dep[v] = dep[u] + 1, Q.push(v), fa[v] = u; } return std::max_element(dep.begin(), dep.end()) - dep.begin(); }; int X = find(0); int Y = find(X); vector<int> a; for (int i = Y; i != -1; i = fa[i]) a.pb(i); vector<pii> ans; int d = a.size(); if (d & 1) { int p = a[d / 2]; for (int i = 0; i <= d / 2; i++) ans.pb({p, i}); } else { int p = a[d / 2], q = a[(d - 1) / 2]; for (int i = 1; i <= d / 2; i += 2) ans.pb({p, i}), ans.pb({q, i}); } cout << ans.size() << '
'; for (auto [x, y] : ans) cout << x + 1 << ' ' << y << '
';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} F1 è¿™æ˜¯é—®é¢˜çš„ç®€å•ç‰ˆæœ¬ã€‚ä¸¤ä¸ªç‰ˆæœ¬çš„å”¯ä¸€åŒºåˆ«åœ¨äºå¯¹ $n$ çš„é™åˆ¶ã€‚åªæœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªç‰ˆæœ¬çš„é—®é¢˜éƒ½è§£å†³äº†ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½è¿›è¡Œç ´è§£ã€‚ ä¸€ä¸ªç”± $m$ ä¸ªéè´Ÿæ•´æ•°ç»„æˆçš„æ•°ç»„ $b$ ä¸­ï¼Œå¦‚æœ $b$ ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰å…ƒç´ éƒ½å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡ä¸‹é¢çš„æ“ä½œä½¿å…¶ç­‰äº $0$ ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ªæ•°ç»„å°±æ˜¯å¥½æ•°ç»„ï¼š é€‰æ‹©ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„ç´¢å¼• $l$ å’Œ $r$ ( $1 \leq l \color{red}{<} r \leq m$ )ï¼Œç„¶åä»æ‰€æœ‰ $b_i$ ä¸­å‡å» $1$ ä½¿å¾— $l \leq i \leq r$ . ç»™ä½ ä¸¤ä¸ªæ­£æ•´æ•° $n$ ï¼Œ $k$ å’Œä¸€ä¸ªè´¨æ•° $p$ ã€‚ åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰é•¿åº¦ä¸º $n$ çš„æ‰€æœ‰ $(k+1)^n$ æ•°ç»„ä¸­ï¼Œå¯¹äºæ‰€æœ‰ $1 \leq i \leq n$ ï¼Œé•¿åº¦ä¸º $0 \leq a_i \leq k$ çš„æ•°ç»„æœ‰å¤šå°‘ä¸ªï¼Ÿ ç”±äºè¿™ä¸ªæ•°å­—å¯èƒ½å¤ªå¤§ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åªè¦æ±‚æ±‚å‡ºå–æ¨¡ $p$ çš„ä¸ªæ•°ã€‚ è§‚å¯Ÿæ€§è´¨é¢˜åˆæ²¡æ‰¾åˆ°æ€§è´¨å“ˆå“ˆ æ¯æ¬¡å¯¹ i çš„æ“ä½œå¿…ç„¶åŒ…å«äº† i - 1 æˆ– i + 1, æ‰€ä»¥ i èƒ½å‡åˆ° 0 çš„å¿…è¦æ¡ä»¶æ˜¯ a[i] <= a[i - 1] + a[i + 1] é‚£ä¹ˆè¿™æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯å……åˆ†çš„å‘¢ï¼Ÿå®˜æ–¹ editorial é‡Œé¢æœ‰å½’çº³æ³•çš„è¯æ˜ã€‚ ä¸å¦¨æ„Ÿæ€§ç†è§£ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼ˆï¼‰ è®¾ç›¸é‚»çš„ä¸‰ä¸ªæ•°ä¸º abcï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¦æ»¡è¶³ b <= a + c, ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯ c >= b - a f[a][b] è¡¨ç¤ºæœ€åä¸¤ä¸ªæ•°åˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯ a, b çš„ä¸ªæ•° é‚£ä¹ˆ f[b][c] å°±ç­‰äºæ‰€æœ‰ b - a <= c çš„ f[a][b] ä¹‹å’Œ [Codeforces 1944F1] Counting Is Fun (Easy Version).cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748495051525354#include <bits/stdc++.h>using namespace std;#define int long longusing pii = std::pair<int, int>;using tuu = std::tuple<int, int, int>;#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string, std::vector;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;// const int INF = 1e18;int n, k, p;void solve(){ n = read(), k = read(), p = read(); vector<vector<int>> f(k + 1, vector<int>(k + 1, 0)); f[0][0] = 1; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { vector<vector<int>> g(k + 1, vector<int>(k + 1, 0)); // g å…ˆå­˜æ°å¥½ c = b - a çš„ï¼Œæœ€åå†æ±‚å’Œ for (int b = 0; b <= k; b++) { for (int a = 0; a <= k; a++) { int c = std::max(0LL, b - a); g[b][c] += f[a][b], g[b][c] %= p; } for (int j = 1; j <= k; j++) g[b][j] += g[b][j - 1], g[b][j] %= p; } f.swap(g); } int ans = 0; for (int a = 0; a <= k; a++) for (int b = 0; b <= a; b++) ans += f[a][b], ans %= p; cout << ans << '
';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;}

"YES" : "NO");}int main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Bä¸€ä¸ªäºŒæ¬¡å¹‚çš„æ€§è´¨åŠ ç®€å•ç»„åˆæ•°å­¦ [Codeforces 1922B] Forming Triangles.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344454647#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>#define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 3e5 + 5;int n, a[N];int b[N];void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); for (int i = 0; i <= n; i++) b[i] = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) b[a[i]]++; long long ans = 0, cnt = 0; for (int i = 0; i <= n; i++) { if (b[i] == 2) ans += cnt; if (b[i] > 2) ans += b[i] * (b[i] - 1) / 2 * cnt + b[i] * (b[i] - 1) * (b[i] - 2) / 6; cnt += b[i]; } printf("%lld
", ans);}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Cæ•°è½´ä¸Š n ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹è·³åˆ°å¦å¤–ä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹çš„ä»£ä»·æ˜¯ æ•°è½´ä¸Šçš„è·ç¦» ä½†æ˜¯å¯ä»¥èŠ±è´¹ 1 çš„ä»£ä»·è·³åˆ°æœ€è¿‘çš„ç‚¹ å¤šæ¬¡è¯¢é—®ä»æŸä¸ªç‚¹åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹çš„æœ€å°ä»£ä»· æ­£ç€åç€é¢„å¤„ç†ä¸‹å³å¯ [Codeforces 1922C] Closest Cities.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344454647#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e5 + 5;int n, m, a[N], b[N];int c[N], d[N];void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); b[1] = 2, b[n] = 1; for (int i = 2; i < n; i++) b[i] = a[i] - a[i - 1] > a[i + 1] - a[i] ? 2 : 1; c[1] = a[1]; for (int i = 1; i < n; i++) c[i + 1] = b[i] == 1 ? c[i] + a[i + 1] - a[i] : c[i] + 1; d[n] = a[n]; for (int i = n; i >= 2; i--) d[i - 1] = b[i] == 1 ? d[i] - 1 : d[i] - a[i] + a[i - 1]; for (int q = read(); q--; ) { int x = read(), y = read(); printf("%d
", x > y ? d[x] - d[y] : c[y] - c[x]); }}int main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Déå¸¸æœ‰å¯å‘æ€§çš„ä¸€é“é¢˜ å¦‚æœåœ¨è¿™ä¸€è½®ä¸­è¿™ä¸ªæ€ªæ²¡æ­»ï¼Œè€Œä¸”ä»–çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªé‚»å±…ä¹Ÿæ²¡æ­»ï¼Œé‚£ä¸‹ä¸€è½®å°±ä¸ç”¨æ£€æŸ¥è¿™ä¸ªæ€ªäº†ã€‚ è¿™ä¸ªæ€§è´¨æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆç”¨å‘¢ï¼Ÿ ç»´æŠ¤ä¸€ä¸ªé›†åˆï¼šä¸‹ä¸€è½®å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ­»äº¡çš„æ€ªç‰©ã€‚ å¦‚ä½•ç»´æŠ¤ï¼Ÿ æ¯ä¸€è½®å¤„ç†æ—¶å¦‚æœä¸€ä¸ªæ€ªç‰©æ­»äº†å°±æŠŠä»–çš„é‚»å±…åŠ å…¥é›†åˆ é›†åˆçš„å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼Ÿ ç¬¬ä¸€è½®é›†åˆå¤§å°ä¸º nã€‚ä¸€è½®ä¸­ï¼Œæ€æ­»ä¸€ä¸ªæ€ªç‰©æœ€å¤šè®©é›†åˆå¤§å° +2ï¼Œæœ€å¤šå°±æ˜¯ n + 2n = 3nã€‚å’Œ n åŒé˜¶ã€‚ å†æƒ³ä¸ªåŠæ³•ç»´æŠ¤æ¯ä¸ªæ€ªç‰©çš„é‚»å±…å³å¯ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œæœ‰å¤šç§å®ç°æ–¹å¼ã€‚e.g. dsu, set. [Codeforces 1922D] Berserk Monsters.cpp >folded123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445#include <bits/stdc++.h>#define ins insertint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 3e5 + 5;int n, a[N], d[N];void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) d[i] = read(); d[0] = d[n + 1] = INT32_MAX, a[0] = a[n + 1] = 0; std::set<int> lft, cur; for (int i = 0; i <= n + 1; i++) lft.ins(i), cur.ins(i); for (; n--; ) { std::set<int> del, ncur; for (int i : cur) { auto it = lft.find(i); if (it == lft.end()) continue; int L = *std::prev(it); int R = *std::next(it); if (a[L] + a[R] > d[i]) del.ins(i), ncur.ins(L), ncur.ins(R); } std::cout << del.size() << ' '; for (auto it : del) lft.erase(it); cur = ncur; } puts("");}int main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Eé€†å¤© cf æ”¾äº†ä¸ª apio2022 åŸé¢˜å‰Šå¼±ç‰ˆ ç»™å®š mï¼Œè¦æ±‚ä½ æ„é€ ä¸€ä¸ªé•¿åº¦åœ¨ 200 ä»¥å†…çš„åºåˆ—ï¼Œæ»¡è¶³åˆšå¥½æœ‰ m ä¸ªä¸Šå‡å­åºåˆ— m <= 10 ^ 18 é¦–å…ˆï¼Œ1, 2, 3, 4, â€¦. n - 1, n è¿™æ ·çš„åºåˆ—å¯ä»¥äº§ç”Ÿ 2 ^ n çš„è´¡çŒ® èµ›æ—¶åœ¨æƒ³ç”¨è‹¥å¹²ä¸ªè¿™æ ·çš„ä¸œè¥¿å‡‘ï¼Œç„¶åçˆ†é•¿åº¦äº†ã€‚ å…¶å®ä¸éœ€è¦ã€‚ ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œ[1â€¦..10] åé¢æ·»åŠ ä¸€ä¸ª 3ï¼Œå°±ä¼šå¤šäº§ç”Ÿ 2 ^ (3 - 1) çš„è´¡çŒ®ï¼ŒäºŒè¿›åˆ¶æ‹†åˆ†å³å¯ æˆ–è€…ï¼Œåœ¨ [minâ€¦â€¦.max] åé¢åŠ ä¸Šä¸€ä¸ª min å¯ä»¥ +1ï¼ŒåŠ ä¸Šä¸€ä¸ª max å¯ä»¥ *2ï¼Œé€’å½’å³å¯ cf ä¸Š tutorial çš„ implement å¾ˆç®€æ´ [Codeforces 1922E] Increasing Subsequences.cpp >folded12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940414243444546#include <stdio.h>#include <string>#include <iostream>#include <algorithm>#include <string.h>#include <vector>#include <queue>#include <set>#include <map>#define int long longint read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}std::vector<int> go(int x){ std::vector<int> res; if (x == 2) res.push_back(0); else if (x & 1) res = go(x - 1), res.push_back(*std::min_element(res.begin(), res.end()) - 1); else res = go(x / 2), res.push_back(*std::max_element(res.begin(), res.end()) + 1); return res;}void solve(){ auto ans = go(read()); std::cout << ans.size() << '
'; for (auto x : ans) std::cout << x << ' '; puts("");}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;}

-x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;const int INF = 1 << 30;int n, a[N];int las[N], sum[N];vector<int> work(){ vector<int> ans(n, n); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { las[i] = a[i] == a[i - 1] ? las[i - 1] : i; sum[i] = sum[i - 1] + a[i]; if (a[i - 1] > a[i]) { ans[i - 1] = 1; continue; } for (int L = 1, R = i - 1; L <= R; ) if (sum[i - 1] - sum[mid - 1] > a[i] and las[i - 1] > mid) ans[i - 1] = i - mid, L = mid + 1; else R = mid - 1; } return ans;}void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); auto l = work(); std::reverse(a + 1, a + 1 + n); auto r = work(); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { int now = std::min(l[i], r[n - 1 - i]); printf("%lld ", now == n ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;const int INF = 1 << 30;// const long long INF = 1LL << 60;int n, a[N], cnt[N], ans;std::vector<int> g[N];void dfs(int u, int fa){ ans += cnt[a[u]]; int tmp = cnt[a[u]]; for (auto v : g[u]) if (v ^ fa) cnt[a[u]] = 1, dfs(v, u); cnt[a[u]] = tmp + 1;}void solve(){ n = read(), ans = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(), g[i].clear(), cnt[i] = 0; for (int i = 1, u, v; i < n; i++) u = read(), v = read(), g[u].pb(v), g[v].pb(u); dfs(1, 0); cout << ans << '\n';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;}

-x : x;}const int N = 1e4 + 5;const int INF = 1 << 30;// const long long INF = 1LL << 60;int n;string inp[N];int buk[4], ans;void solve(){ string s, t; cin >> s >> t; buk[0] = buk[1] = buk[2] = buk[3] = 0; for (auto ch : t) buk[ch - 'A'] = 1; int cnt = 0; for (auto ch : s) { if (buk[ch - 'A'] != 1) { cnt = 5; break; } else cnt++; } if (cnt == 5) return; else if (cnt == t.size() and t.size() == 1) ans += 3; else if (cnt == t.size()) ans += 5; else ans += 2;}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("A.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); cout << ans; return 0;} B[UIC 1031] ç»Ÿè®¡.cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041#include <bits/stdc++.h>#define int long long#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 2e5 + 5;const int INF = 1 << 30;// const long long INF = 1LL << 60;int n, q, a[N], lft[N], rgt[N], bel[N];void solve(){ n = read(), q = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) lft[i] = a[i] == a[i - 1] ? lft[i - 1] : i; for (int i = n; i >= 1; i--) rgt[i] = a[i] == a[i + 1] ? rgt[i + 1] : i; int nodecnt = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) bel[i] = nodecnt, nodecnt += (rgt[i] == i); // for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) cout << bel[i] << ' '; // puts("-------"); // for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) for (int l, r; q; q--) { l = read(), r = read(); cout << bel[r] - bel[l] + 1 << '

';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("C.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;} Dè´´ä¸‹ solï¼Œè®²çš„å¾ˆæ¸…æ™°äº† ä¸éš¾å‘ç°ï¼Œå¯¹äºæ¯ä¸€åˆ—ï¼Œä¸€å®šæ˜¯ä»æœ€å¤§çš„å¼€å§‹é€‰æ‹©ã€‚è€Œä¸”ä¸åŒåˆ—ä¹‹é—´çš„é€‰æ‹©æ˜¯ç‹¬ç«‹çš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¯ä»¥å…ˆç»™æ¯ä¸€åˆ—å•ç‹¬ä»å¤§åˆ°å°æ’åºï¼Œç„¶åå†è¿›è¡Œåç»­åˆ†æã€‚é€‰æ‹©çš„è¿™ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹å®é™…ä¸Šå¯ä»¥çœ‹ä½œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¤§å°ä¸º N Ã— K çš„çª—å£ä»å·¦å¾€å³æ»‘åŠ¨ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”è¿™ä¸ª çª—å£æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¸Šä¸‰è§’çš„ï¼Œå³å¯¹äºçª—å£çš„ç¬¬ i åˆ—ï¼Œæœ€å¤šåªèƒ½é€‰æ‹©å‰ i ä¸ªç‰©å“ã€‚å¹¶ä¸”å¦‚æœä¸€æ¬¡ æ€§é€‰æ‹©äº† j ä¸ªï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ªçª—å£è¿˜ä¼šå‘å³ä¸€æ¬¡æ€§æ»‘åŠ¨ j ä¸ªå•ä½ã€‚è®¾ f[i,j] è¡¨ç¤ºå½“å‰çª—å£å·¦ç«¯ç‚¹åœ¨ç¬¬ i åˆ—ï¼Œä¸”å½“å‰è€ƒè™‘åˆ°çš„æ˜¯æ•´ä¸ªåºåˆ—çš„ç¬¬ j åˆ—æ—¶æ”¶è·çš„æœ€å¤§ç”µå­å¸ä¹‹å’Œã€‚è½¬ç§»çš„è¯ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦æšä¸¾ç¬¬ j åˆ—é€‰æ‹©äº†å¤šå°‘ä¸ªå°±è¡Œ [UIC 1033] ç”µå­é’±åŒ….cpp >folded1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738394041424344454647484950#include <bits/stdc++.h>#define int long long#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int M = 1e5 + 5;const int N = 10 + 5;int n, m, k, a[N][M], sum[N][M], f[N][M];void solve(){ n = read(), m = read(), k = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++) a[i][j] = read(); for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++) { std::vector<int> b(n); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) b[i - 1] = a[i][j]; std::sort(b.rbegin(), b.rend()); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i][j] = b[i - 1]; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i][j] += a[i - 1][j]; } for (int i = 1; i + k - 1 <= m; i++) for (int j = i; j <= i + k - 1; j++) { int len = j - i + 1; for (int c = 0; c <= len and i + k - 1 + c <= m + 1; c++) f[len - c + 1][i + c] = std::max(f[len - c + 1][i + c], f[len][i] + a[c][j]); } int ans = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= k; i++) for (int j = 0; j <= m + 1; j++) ans = std::max(ans, f[i][j]); cout << ans;}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("D.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = 1; T--; solve()); return 0;} Eçœ‹æˆæ•°è½´ä¸Šçš„è‹¥å¹²æ¡çº¿æ®µï¼Œsum æ˜¯è¿™ n æ¡çº¿æ®µé•¿åº¦çš„å’Œ æ‰‹ç©ä¸€ä¸‹äº¤æ¢ä¸€æ¡çº¿æ®µï¼Œå‘ç°åªæœ‰ä¸¤æ¡çº¿æ®µä¸äº¤çš„æ—¶å€™æ‰ä¼šä½¿ç­”æ¡ˆå˜å¤§ [UIC 1034] ç»å¯¹å€¼.cpp >folded12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940#include <bits/stdc++.h>#define int long long#define pb push_backusing std::cin, std::cout, std::string;int read(int x = 0, int f = 0, char ch = getchar()){ while (ch < 48 or 57 < ch) f = ch == 45, ch = getchar(); while(48 <= ch and ch <= 57) x = x * 10 + ch - 48, ch = getchar(); return f ? -x : x;}const int N = 1e6 + 5;// const long long INF = 1LL << 60;int n, a[N], b[N];void solve(){ n = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) a[i] = read(); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) b[i] = read(); int ans = 0; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) ans += abs(a[i] - b[i]); int sum = ans, p = 1, q = 1; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { if (std::max(a[i], b[i]) < std::max(a[p], b[p])) p = i; if (std::min(a[i], b[i]) > std::min(a[q], b[q])) q = i; } for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) ans = std::max(ans, sum - abs(a[i] - b[i]) - abs(a[p] - b[p]) + abs(a[i] - b[p]) + abs(a[p] - b[i])), ans = std::max(ans, sum - abs(a[i] - b[i]) - abs(a[q] - b[q]) + abs(a[i] - b[q]) + abs(a[q] - b[i])); cout << ans << '
';}signed main(){#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE freopen("E.in", "r", stdin);#endif for (int T = read(); T--; solve()); return 0;}

posts.text: Toyota Programming Contest 2024#4ï¼ˆAtCoder Beginner Contest 348ï¼‰ å¹´è½»äººçš„ç¬¬ä¸€åœº abc 2024/04/06 æ‰“çš„ï¼Œ2024/06/20 è¡¥äº†ä¸‹é¢˜è§£ æ¯”èµ›é“¾æ¥ Problems AC A. Penalty Kick â—‹ B. Ordinal: Education level (high school, bachelorâ€™s, masterâ€™s). Interval: Temperature (Celsius). Ratio: Height (cm). Statistical Analysis ç»Ÿè®¡åˆ†æDescriptive Statistics æè¿°ç»Ÿè®¡ Frequency Distribution é¢‘æ•°åˆ†å¸ƒ Count or frequency for nominal/categorical data. åä¹‰/åˆ†ç±»æ•°æ®çš„è®¡æ•°æˆ–é¢‘ç‡ã€‚ Measures of spread out or dispersed scores are in a distribution. åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­åˆ†æ•°çš„åˆ†æ•£ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Range, standard deviation (SD), variance (VAR), interquartile range (IQR). èŒƒå›´ã€æ ‡å‡†å·®ï¼ˆSDï¼‰ã€æ–¹å·®ï¼ˆVARï¼‰ã€å››åˆ†ä½è·ï¼ˆIQRï¼‰ã€‚ Inferential Statistics æ¨è®ºç»Ÿè®¡ Inferential Statistics æ¨è®ºç»Ÿè®¡ Makes inferences and predictions about a population based on a sample of data. åŸºäºæ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®å¯¹æ€»ä½“è¿›è¡Œæ¨æ–­å’Œé¢„æµ‹ã€‚ Provide a way to test a claim or hypothesis using sample data. æä¾›ä¸€ç§ä½¿ç”¨æ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®æ£€éªŒä¸»å¼ æˆ–å‡è®¾çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ Hypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒNull Hypothesis é›¶å‡è®¾ Definition å®šä¹‰ No relationship (â€œno differenceâ€) between variables in the population is expected. é¢„è®¡æ€»ä½“ä¸­å˜é‡ä¹‹é—´æ²¡æœ‰å…³ç³»ï¼ˆâ€œæ²¡æœ‰å·®å¼‚â€ï¼‰ã€‚ Alternative Hypothesis å¤‡æ‹©å‡è®¾ Definition å®šä¹‰ A relationship (â€œa differenceâ€) between variables in the population is expected. é¢„è®¡æ€»ä½“ä¸­å˜é‡ä¹‹é—´æœ‰å…³ç³»ï¼ˆâ€œæœ‰å·®å¼‚â€ï¼‰ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Significance Testing æ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ£€éªŒ If the observed p-value is less than a predefined value (alpha, Î±), the null hypothesis can be rejected. å¦‚æœè§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°çš„på€¼å°äºé¢„å®šä¹‰å€¼ï¼ˆalphaï¼ŒÎ±ï¼‰ï¼Œåˆ™å¯ä»¥æ‹’ç»é›¶å‡è®¾ã€‚ Common alpha level: Î± = 0.05. å¸¸è§çš„alphaæ°´å¹³ï¼šÎ± = 0.05ã€‚ Possible Errors å¯èƒ½çš„é”™è¯¯ Type I Error ç±»å‹Ié”™è¯¯ Rejecting a true null hypothesis (false positive). æ‹’ç»æ­£ç¡®çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ï¼ˆå‡é˜³æ€§ï¼‰ã€‚ Type II Error ç±»å‹IIé”™è¯¯ Failing to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative). æœªèƒ½æ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ï¼ˆå‡é˜´æ€§ï¼‰ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Power åŠŸæ•ˆ The chance of rejecting a false null hypothesis. æ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾çš„æœºä¼šã€‚ Power = 1 - Î² (where Î² is the probability of a Type II error). åŠŸæ•ˆ = 1 - Î²ï¼ˆå…¶ä¸­Î²æ˜¯ç±»å‹IIé”™è¯¯çš„æ¦‚ç‡ï¼‰ã€‚ Beyond Hypothesis Testing è¶…è¶Šå‡è®¾æ£€éªŒConfidence Intervals ç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´ Definition å®šä¹‰ The range within which the population mean is likely to be found within a percentage of the time. æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼å¯èƒ½åœ¨ä¸€å®šç™¾åˆ†æ¯”æ—¶é—´å†…å‡ºç°çš„èŒƒå›´ã€‚ Example: A 95% confidence interval tells us that we can be 95% confident that the interval captures the population mean. ä¾‹å­ï¼š95%çš„ç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´å‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘ä»¬ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥95%ç¡®å®šè¯¥åŒºé—´åŒ…å«æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼ã€‚ Effect Size æ•ˆåº”é‡ Definition å®šä¹‰ Emphasizes the size of the difference between variables, not merely whether there is a difference. å¼ºè°ƒå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´å·®å¼‚çš„å¤§å°ï¼Œè€Œä¸ä»…ä»…æ˜¯æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨å·®å¼‚ã€‚ Open Science, Pre-registration, and Replications å¼€æ”¾ç§‘å­¦ã€é¢„æ³¨å†Œå’Œå¤åˆ¶ç ”ç©¶Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Open Science å¼€æ”¾ç§‘å­¦ Promotes transparency and accessibility in scientific research. ä¿ƒè¿›ç§‘å­¦ç ”ç©¶çš„é€æ˜æ€§å’Œå¯è®¿é—®æ€§ã€‚ Pre-registration é¢„æ³¨å†Œ Registering study design and analysis plans before conducting the research. åœ¨è¿›è¡Œç ”ç©¶ä¹‹å‰æ³¨å†Œç ”ç©¶è®¾è®¡å’Œåˆ†æè®¡åˆ’ã€‚ Replications å¤åˆ¶ç ”ç©¶ Repeating studies to confirm findings and ensure reliability. é‡å¤ç ”ç©¶ä»¥ç¡®è®¤å‘ç°å¹¶ç¡®ä¿å¯é æ€§ã€‚ Summary æ€»ç»“ Various sampling procedures are available to find a representative sample from the population. æœ‰å¤šç§æŠ½æ ·ç¨‹åºå¯ç”¨äºä»æ€»ä½“ä¸­æ‰¾åˆ°å…·æœ‰ä»£è¡¨æ€§çš„æ ·æœ¬ã€‚ Statistics is the language used to communicate findings in the field of psychology. ç»Ÿè®¡æ˜¯å¿ƒç†å­¦é¢†åŸŸä¸­ç”¨äºäº¤æµå‘ç°çš„è¯­è¨€ã€‚ Hypothesis testing involves determining the likelihood that the observed results are due to chance. å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒæ¶‰åŠç¡®å®šè§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°çš„ç»“æœæ˜¯ç”±äºæœºä¼šçš„å¯èƒ½æ€§ã€‚ Beyond hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, effect sizes, and power are essential for understanding psychological phenomena. è¶…è¶Šå‡è®¾æ£€éªŒï¼Œç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´ã€æ•ˆåº”é‡å’ŒåŠŸæ•ˆå¯¹äºç†è§£å¿ƒç†ç°è±¡è‡³å…³é‡è¦ã€‚

posts.text: PSY2013 Research Methods in Psychology Ch05 Introduction to Experimental Research Ch06 Methodological Control in Experimental Research What is an Experiment? ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯å®éªŒï¼Ÿ Experiment å®éªŒ ç ”ç©¶è°ƒæŸ¥è‡³å°‘ä¸€ä¸ªè‡ªå˜é‡ (IV) X å¯¹è‡³å°‘ä¸€ä¸ªå› å˜é‡ (DV) Y çš„å½±å“ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä¿æŒæ‰€æœ‰å…¶ä»–å› ç´ ä¸å˜ã€‚ Independent Variable (IV) è‡ªå˜é‡ (IV): The manipulated variable that is believed to be the cause. è¢«è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯åŸå› çš„æ“ä½œå˜é‡ã€‚ Dependent Variable (DV) å› å˜é‡ (DV): The measured variable that is the outcome. ç»“æœçš„æµ‹é‡å˜é‡ã€‚ Extraneous Variables å¤–åœ¨å˜é‡: Factors held constant. ä¿æŒä¸å˜çš„å› ç´ ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Woodworthâ€™s â€˜Columbia Bibleâ€™ (1938): First distinguished between independent and dependent variables in experiments and showed preference for experimental over correlational research. (X -> Y) X æ˜¯å¦å¯¼è‡´ Yï¼Ÿ ä¾‹å­ï¼šé”»ç‚¼æ˜¯å¦å¯¼è‡´å¥åº·ï¼Ÿå¸çƒŸæ˜¯å¦å¯¼è‡´è‚ºç™Œï¼Ÿ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Criterions for Causation å› æœå…³ç³»çš„æ ‡å‡† Association å…³è”: Two variables are observed to vary together. ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡è¢«è§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°ä¸€èµ·å˜åŒ–ã€‚ Time Order æ—¶é—´é¡ºåº: One variable comes first in time before the other variable. ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é‡åœ¨æ—¶é—´ä¸Šå…ˆäºå¦ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é‡ã€‚ Nonspuriousness éè™šå‡æ€§: Other possible explanations can be ruled out. å…¶ä»–å¯èƒ½çš„è§£é‡Šå¯ä»¥æ’é™¤ã€‚ Mechanism æœºåˆ¶: The process that creates a causal connection between two variables. åˆ›é€ ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´å› æœå…³ç³»çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚ The Logic of Experimental Research å®éªŒç ”ç©¶çš„é€»è¾‘ John Stuart Millâ€™s Inductive Logic çº¦ç¿°Â·æ–¯å›¾å°”ç‰¹Â·å¯†å°”çš„å½’çº³é€»è¾‘ Method of Agreement ä¸€è‡´æ³• If X, then Y (sufficiency -> X is sufficient for Y). å¦‚æœæœ‰ Xï¼Œåˆ™æœ‰ Yï¼ˆå……åˆ†æ¡ä»¶ -> X è¶³ä»¥å¯¼è‡´ Yï¼‰ã€‚ Method of Difference å·®å¼‚æ³• If not X, then not Y (necessity -> X is necessary for Y). å¦‚æœæ²¡æœ‰ Xï¼Œåˆ™æ²¡æœ‰ Yï¼ˆå¿…è¦æ¡ä»¶ -> X æ˜¯ Y æ‰€å¿…éœ€çš„ï¼‰ã€‚ Together, these methods enable us to conclude, with a high degree of confidence (but not absolute certainty), that X causes Y. ç»“åˆè¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é«˜åº¦ç¡®ä¿¡ï¼ˆä½†ä¸æ˜¯ç»å¯¹ç¡®å®šï¼‰X å¯¼è‡´ Yã€‚ Essential Features of Experimental Research å®éªŒç ”ç©¶çš„åŸºæœ¬ç‰¹å¾Establishing Independent Variables (IVs) ç¡®ç«‹è‡ªå˜é‡ (IV) Types of IVs è‡ªå˜é‡çš„ç±»å‹ Situational æƒ…å¢ƒæ€§: Different conditions or contexts. ä¸åŒçš„æ¡ä»¶æˆ–æƒ…å¢ƒã€‚ Task ä»»åŠ¡æ€§: Different tasks participants perform. å‚ä¸è€…æ‰§è¡Œçš„ä¸åŒä»»åŠ¡ã€‚ Instructional æŒ‡å¯¼æ€§: Different instructions given to participants. ç»™å‚ä¸è€…çš„ä¸åŒæŒ‡ç¤ºã€‚ Experimental Group å®éªŒç»„ Given treatment. æ¥å—å¤„ç†ã€‚ Control Group æ§åˆ¶ç»„ Treatment withheld. ä¸æ¥å—å¤„ç†ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Manipulate Situational IV æ“ä½œæƒ…å¢ƒæ€§è‡ªå˜é‡ Example: Personal space invasions in the lavatory by Middlemis (1976). ä¾‹å­ï¼šMiddlemis (1976) åœ¨æ´—æ‰‹é—´çš„ä¸ªäººç©ºé—´ä¾µçŠ¯å®éªŒã€‚ Manipulate Task IV æ“ä½œä»»åŠ¡æ€§è‡ªå˜é‡ Example: Bushman and Anderson (2009) study on video games. ä¾‹å­ï¼šBushman å’Œ Anderson (2009) å…³äºç”µå­æ¸¸æˆçš„ç ”ç©¶ã€‚ Manipulate Instructional IV æ“ä½œæŒ‡å¯¼æ€§è‡ªå˜é‡ Example: Priming study by Dijksterhuis and Knippenberg (1998). ä¾‹å­ï¼šDijksterhuis å’Œ Knippenberg (1998) çš„å¯åŠ¨ç ”ç©¶ã€‚ Controlling Extraneous Variables (EVs) æ§åˆ¶å¤–åœ¨å˜é‡ (EV) Confounds æ··æ·†å˜é‡ Any uncontrolled extraneous variable. ä»»ä½•æœªæ§åˆ¶çš„å¤–åœ¨å˜é‡ã€‚ Results could be due to IV or due to confound. ç»“æœå¯èƒ½æ˜¯ç”±äºè‡ªå˜é‡æˆ–æ··æ·†å˜é‡ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Example ä¾‹å­ Distributed practice study with different study schedules. ä¸åŒå­¦ä¹ æ—¶é—´è¡¨çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå¼ç»ƒä¹ ç ”ç©¶ã€‚ Measuring Dependent Variables (DVs) æµ‹é‡å› å˜é‡ (DVs) Dependent Variables å› å˜é‡ Any behaviors measured in an experiment. åœ¨å®éªŒä¸­æµ‹é‡çš„ä»»ä½•è¡Œä¸ºã€‚ å›é¡¾æµ‹é‡å°ºåº¦ï¼ˆåä¹‰ã€é¡ºåºã€é—´éš”ã€æ¯”ç‡ï¼‰ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Problems é—®é¢˜ Ceiling Effects å¤©èŠ±æ¿æ•ˆåº”: Task is too easy, all scores very high. ä»»åŠ¡å¤ªå®¹æ˜“ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰åˆ†æ•°éƒ½å¾ˆé«˜ã€‚ Floor Effects åœ°æ¿æ•ˆåº”: Task is too difficult, all scores very low. ä»»åŠ¡å¤ªéš¾ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰åˆ†æ•°éƒ½å¾ˆä½ã€‚ Subject Variables å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡Definition å®šä¹‰ Subject Variables å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡ Already-existing attributes of subjects in a study. ç ”ç©¶ä¸­å—è¯•è€…çš„æ—¢æœ‰å±æ€§ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Examples ä¾‹å­ Gender, age, religion, SES, personality characteristic. æ€§åˆ«ã€å¹´é¾„ã€å®—æ•™ã€ç¤¾ä¼šç»æµåœ°ä½ã€æ€§æ ¼ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ Drawing Conclusions with Subject Variables ä½¿ç”¨å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡å¾—å‡ºç»“è®º With a Manipulated IV ä½¿ç”¨æ“ä½œè‡ªå˜é‡ Assuming no confounds -> IV causes DV. å‡è®¾æ²¡æœ‰æ··æ·†å˜é‡ -> è‡ªå˜é‡å¯¼è‡´å› å˜é‡ã€‚ With a Subject Variable ä½¿ç”¨å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡ Groups may differ in several ways -> IV cannot be said to cause DV. å„ç»„å¯èƒ½åœ¨å¤šæ–¹é¢æœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒ -> ä¸èƒ½è¯´è‡ªå˜é‡å¯¼è‡´å› å˜é‡ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Example ä¾‹å­ Self-esteem study with manipulated IV (feedback on test performance) and subject variable (low vs. high self-esteem). è‡ªå°Šç ”ç©¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æ“ä½œè‡ªå˜é‡ï¼ˆæµ‹è¯•è¡¨ç°åé¦ˆï¼‰å’Œå—è¯•è€…å˜é‡ï¼ˆä½ vs. é«˜è‡ªå°Šï¼‰ã€‚ The Validity of Experimental Research å®éªŒç ”ç©¶çš„æ•ˆåº¦Types of Validity æ•ˆåº¦ç±»å‹ Statistical Conclusion Validity ç»Ÿè®¡ç»“è®ºæ•ˆåº¦ The extent a researcher uses statistics properly and draws the appropriate conclusions from the statistical analysis. ç ”ç©¶äººå‘˜é€‚å½“ä½¿ç”¨ç»Ÿè®¡æ–¹æ³•å¹¶ä»ç»Ÿè®¡åˆ†æä¸­å¾—å‡ºé€‚å½“ç»“è®ºçš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Construct Validity æ„å¿µæ•ˆåº¦ The extent to which the abstract construct can be inferred from the operational definition. ä»æ“ä½œå®šä¹‰æ¨æ–­æŠ½è±¡æ„å¿µçš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ External Validity å¤–éƒ¨æ•ˆåº¦ The extent to which research findings generalize to contexts other than those of the experiment. ç ”ç©¶å‘ç°æ¨å¹¿åˆ°å®éªŒä»¥å¤–ç¯å¢ƒçš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Internal Validity å†…éƒ¨æ•ˆåº¦ The degree to which an experiment is methodologically sound and confound-free. å®éªŒåœ¨æ–¹æ³•ä¸Šæ˜¯å¦å¥å…¨å’Œæ²¡æœ‰æ··æ·†å˜é‡çš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Threats to Internal Validity å†…éƒ¨æ•ˆåº¦çš„å¨èƒ History å†å²æ•ˆåº”: Results from a historical or external factor affecting the experimental group. ç”±äºå½±å“å®éªŒç»„çš„å†å²æˆ–å¤–éƒ¨å› ç´ å¯¼è‡´çš„ç»“æœã€‚ Maturation æˆç†Ÿæ•ˆåº”: Participants naturally change over time, independent of their participation in the study. å‚ä¸è€…éšç€æ—¶é—´è‡ªç„¶å˜åŒ–ï¼Œä¸ä»–ä»¬å‚ä¸ç ”ç©¶æ— å…³ã€‚ Regression to the Mean å‡å€¼å›å½’: æç«¯åˆ†æ•°åœ¨éšåçš„æµ‹è¯•ä¸­å¾€å¾€ä¼šè¶‹å‘äºå¹³å‡å€¼ã€‚ Testing and Instrumentation æµ‹è¯•å’Œä»ªå™¨æ•ˆåº”: éšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æ¨ç§»ï¼Œå‚ä¸è€…æˆ–æµ‹é‡å·¥å…·çš„å˜åŒ–ã€‚ Subject Selection å—è¯•è€…é€‰æ‹©: Groups are not equivalent. å„ç»„ä¸ç­‰ä»·ã€‚ Attrition é€€å‡ºæ•ˆåº”: Reduction in participant numbers due to dropouts. ç”±äºé€€å‡ºå¯¼è‡´çš„å‚ä¸è€…äººæ•°å‡å°‘ã€‚ --- Methodological Control æ–¹æ³•æ§åˆ¶Between-Subjects and Within-Subjects Design è¢«è¯•é—´è®¾è®¡å’Œè¢«è¯•å†…è®¾è®¡ Between-Subjects Design è¢«è¯•é—´è®¾è®¡ Each subject experiences only one level of the variable. æ¯ä¸ªå—è¯•è€…ä»…ç»å†ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é‡æ°´å¹³ã€‚ Solved by random assignment or matching. é€šè¿‡éšæœºåˆ†é…æˆ–åŒ¹é…è§£å†³ã€‚ Random Assignment éšæœºåˆ†é… Definition å®šä¹‰ A procedure in which each participant has an equal chance of being assigned to any group in an experiment. ä¸€ç§ç¨‹åºï¼Œä½¿æ¯ä¸ªå‚ä¸è€…æœ‰å¹³ç­‰æœºä¼šè¢«åˆ†é…åˆ°å®éªŒä¸­çš„ä»»ä½•ç»„ã€‚ Ensures that groups are equivalent at the start of the experiment. ç¡®ä¿å„ç»„åœ¨å®éªŒå¼€å§‹æ—¶æ˜¯ç­‰ä»·çš„ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Example ä¾‹å­ In a study on the effects of a new drug, participants are randomly assigned to either the treatment group or the control group. åœ¨ä¸€é¡¹å…³äºæ–°è¯æ•ˆæœçš„ç ”ç©¶ä¸­ï¼Œå‚ä¸è€…è¢«éšæœºåˆ†é…åˆ°æ²»ç–—ç»„æˆ–å¯¹ç…§ç»„ã€‚ Matching é…å¯¹ Definition å®šä¹‰ A procedure to ensure that groups are equivalent by matching participants on specific characteristics before assigning them to groups. ä¸€ç§é€šè¿‡åœ¨åˆ†ç»„ä¹‹å‰æ ¹æ®ç‰¹å®šç‰¹å¾åŒ¹é…å‚ä¸è€…ä»¥ç¡®ä¿å„ç»„ç­‰ä»·çš„ç¨‹åºã€‚ Used when random assignment is not feasible or when there are known confounding variables. åœ¨éšæœºåˆ†é…ä¸å¯è¡Œæˆ–å­˜åœ¨å·²çŸ¥æ··æ·†å˜é‡æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Example ä¾‹å­ In a study on the effects of teaching methods on student performance, participants are matched on GPA before being assigned to different teaching methods. åœ¨ä¸€é¡¹å…³äºæ•™å­¦æ–¹æ³•å¯¹å­¦ç”Ÿè¡¨ç°å½±å“çš„ç ”ç©¶ä¸­ï¼Œå‚ä¸è€…åœ¨åˆ†é…åˆ°ä¸åŒçš„æ•™å­¦æ–¹æ³•ä¹‹å‰æ ¹æ® GPA è¿›è¡ŒåŒ¹é…ã€‚ Within-Subjects Design è¢«è¯•å†…è®¾è®¡ Each subject experiences all levels of the variable. æ¯ä¸ªå—è¯•è€…ç»å†æ‰€æœ‰å˜é‡æ°´å¹³ã€‚ Solved by counterbalancing. é€šè¿‡å¹³è¡¡è§£å†³ã€‚ Counterbalancing å¹³è¡¡è®¾è®¡ Definition å®šä¹‰ A method to control for order effects in a within-subjects design by varying the order of conditions for participants. ä¸€ç§åœ¨è¢«è¯•å†…è®¾è®¡ä¸­æ§åˆ¶é¡ºåºæ•ˆåº”çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œé€šè¿‡æ”¹å˜å‚ä¸è€…çš„æ¡ä»¶é¡ºåºã€‚ Types ç±»å‹ Complete Counterbalancing å®Œå…¨å¹³è¡¡ All possible orders of conditions are used equally. æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½çš„æ¡ä»¶é¡ºåºéƒ½åŒç­‰ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚ Example: For 3 conditions (A, B, C), there are 6 possible orders (ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA). ä¾‹å­ï¼šå¯¹äº3ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶ï¼ˆA, B, Cï¼‰ï¼Œæœ‰6ç§å¯èƒ½çš„é¡ºåºï¼ˆABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBAï¼‰ã€‚ Partial Counterbalancing éƒ¨åˆ†å¹³è¡¡ Only a subset of all possible orders is used. ä»…ä½¿ç”¨æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½é¡ºåºçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­é›†ã€‚ Often achieved through a Latin Square design. é€šå¸¸é€šè¿‡æ‹‰ä¸æ–¹è®¾è®¡å®ç°ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Latin Square Design æ‹‰ä¸æ–¹è®¾è®¡ A special case of partial counterbalancing where each condition appears in each position and precedes and follows each other condition exactly once. éƒ¨åˆ†å¹³è¡¡çš„ç‰¹æ®Šæƒ…å†µï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æ¯ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶å‡ºç°åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªä½ç½®ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æ¯ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶æ°å¥½ä¸€æ¬¡å‡ºç°åœ¨å…¶ä»–æ¡ä»¶ä¹‹å‰å’Œä¹‹åã€‚ Example ä¾‹å­: Example of Counterbalancing å¹³è¡¡ç¤ºä¾‹ Testing the effect of different study techniques (reading, summarizing, testing) on memory retention. æµ‹è¯•ä¸åŒå­¦ä¹ æŠ€æœ¯ï¼ˆé˜…è¯»ï¼Œæ€»ç»“ï¼Œæµ‹è¯•ï¼‰å¯¹è®°å¿†ä¿æŒçš„å½±å“ã€‚ Complete counterbalancing: Participants experience all 6 orders of the 3 conditions. å®Œå…¨å¹³è¡¡ï¼šå‚ä¸è€…ç»å†æ‰€æœ‰3ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶çš„6ç§é¡ºåºã€‚ Partial counterbalancing: Using a Latin Square, participants experience a subset of all possible orders. éƒ¨åˆ†å¹³è¡¡ï¼šä½¿ç”¨æ‹‰ä¸æ–¹ï¼Œå‚ä¸è€…ç»å†æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½é¡ºåºçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­é›†ã€‚ Controlling for Bias æ§åˆ¶åè§ Experimenter Bias å®éªŒè€…åè§ Expectations can influence subject behavior. æœŸæœ›å¯èƒ½å½±å“å—è¯•è€…è¡Œä¸ºã€‚ Solution: Automatize routine, standardize procedures, use double-blind procedures. è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼šè‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–å¸¸è§„ï¼Œæ ‡å‡†åŒ–ç¨‹åºï¼Œä½¿ç”¨åŒç›²ç¨‹åºã€‚ Participant Bias å‚ä¸è€…åè§ Participants change behavior because they are being observed. å‚ä¸è€…å› ä¸ºè¢«è§‚å¯Ÿè€Œæ”¹å˜è¡Œä¸ºã€‚ Solution: Effective deception, use of manipulation checks, field Statistics æ¨è®ºç»Ÿè®¡ Definition å®šä¹‰ Methods for using sample data to make general conclusions about populations. ä½¿ç”¨æ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®å¯¹æ€»ä½“åšå‡ºä¸€èˆ¬ç»“è®ºçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ z-Scores æ ‡å‡†åˆ†æ•° ä¸­å¿ƒæé™å®šç† Definition å®šä¹‰ The distribution of sample means will be normal if the sample size is large enough (n â‰¥ 30). å¦‚æœæ ·æœ¬é‡è¶³å¤Ÿå¤§ï¼ˆn â‰¥ 30ï¼‰ï¼Œæ ·æœ¬å‡å€¼çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå°†æ˜¯æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚ Properties ç‰¹æ€§ Mean of sample means = Population mean æ ·æœ¬å‡å€¼çš„å¹³å‡æ•° = æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼ Standard Error æ ‡å‡†è¯¯å·®: $$\sigma_M = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$$ Part 3: Hypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒHypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒ Definition å®šä¹‰ Statistical method that uses sample data to evaluate a hypothesis about a population. ä½¿ç”¨æ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®è¯„ä¼°æ€»ä½“å‡è®¾çš„ç»Ÿè®¡æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ Steps æ­¥éª¤ State hypothesis about the population. é™ˆè¿°å…³äºæ€»ä½“çš„å‡è®¾ã€‚ Use hypothesis to predict the characteristics the sample should have. ä½¿ç”¨å‡è®¾é¢„æµ‹æ ·æœ¬åº”å…·æœ‰çš„ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ Obtain a sample from the population. ä»æ€»ä½“ä¸­è·å–æ ·æœ¬ã€‚ Compare data with the hypothesis prediction. å°†æ•°æ®ä¸å‡è®¾é¢„æµ‹è¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒã€‚ Null Hypothesis (H0) é›¶å‡è®¾ States that there is no change or effect. å£°æ˜æ²¡æœ‰å˜åŒ–æˆ–æ•ˆæœã€‚ Alternative Hypothesis (H1) å¤‡æ‹©å‡è®¾ States that there is a change or effect. å£°æ˜å­˜åœ¨å˜åŒ–æˆ–æ•ˆæœã€‚ Critical Regions and Alpha Level ä¸´ç•ŒåŒºå’Œæ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³ Critical Region ä¸´ç•ŒåŒº Extreme sample values that are very unlikely to occur if H0 is true. å¦‚æœé›¶å‡è®¾æˆç«‹ï¼Œæä¸å¯èƒ½å‘ç”Ÿçš„æ ·æœ¬å€¼ã€‚ Alpha Level (Î±) æ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³ Probability value used to define â€œvery unlikelyâ€ outcomes. ç”¨äºå®šä¹‰â€œæä¸å¯èƒ½â€ç»“æœçš„æ¦‚ç‡å€¼ã€‚ Common Î± values å¸¸ç”¨Î±å€¼: 0.05, 0.01, 0.001 Errors in Hypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒä¸­çš„é”™è¯¯ Type I Error (Î±) ä¸€ç±»é”™è¯¯ Rejecting H0 when it is true. æ‹’ç»æˆç«‹çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ã€‚ False positive å‡é˜³æ€§ Type II Error (Î²) äºŒç±»é”™è¯¯ Failing to reject H0 when it is false. æœªæ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ã€‚ False negative å‡é˜´æ€§ Statistical Power ç»Ÿè®¡åŠŸæ•ˆ Definition å®šä¹‰ Probability that the test will correctly reject a false null hypothesis. æ£€éªŒæ­£ç¡®æ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾çš„æ¦‚ç‡ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$\text{Power} = 1 - \beta$$ Measuring Effect Size æµ‹é‡æ•ˆæœå¤§å° Cohenâ€™s d ç§‘æ©çš„d Measures the size of the mean difference in terms of standard deviation units. ä»¥æ ‡å‡†å·®å•ä½è¡¡é‡å¹³å‡å·®å¼‚çš„å¤§å°ã€‚ Part 4: t-Tests tæ£€éªŒThe t Statistic tç»Ÿè®¡é‡ Definition å®šä¹‰ Used to test hypotheses about an unknown population mean when the population standard deviation is also unknown. ç”¨äºåœ¨æ€»ä½“æ ‡å‡†å·®æœªçŸ¥çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹æ£€éªŒæœªçŸ¥æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼çš„å‡è®¾ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$t = \frac{M - \mu}{s_M}$$ $s_M$: Estimated standard error ä¼°è®¡æ ‡å‡†è¯¯å·® Degrees of Freedom è‡ªç”±åº¦ Definition å®šä¹‰ Number of scores in a sample that are independent and free to vary. æ ·æœ¬ä¸­ç‹¬ç«‹ä¸”è‡ªç”±å˜åŒ–çš„åˆ†æ•°æ•°é‡ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$df = n - 1$$ Hypothesis Tests with the t Statistic ä½¿ç”¨tç»Ÿè®¡é‡çš„å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒ Steps æ­¥éª¤ State the hypotheses and select an alpha level. é™ˆè¿°å‡è®¾å¹¶é€‰æ‹©æ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³ã€‚ Locate the critical region using df and alpha level. ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªç”±åº¦å’Œæ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³æ‰¾åˆ°ä¸´ç•ŒåŒºã€‚ Calculate the test statistic. è®¡ç®—æ£€éªŒç»Ÿè®¡é‡ã€‚ Make a decision. åšå‡ºå†³å®šã€‚ Independent-Measures t Test ç‹¬ç«‹æ ·æœ¬tæ£€éªŒ Purpose ç›®çš„ Determine whether the sample mean difference indicates a real mean difference between two populations. ç¡®å®šæ ·æœ¬å‡å€¼å·®å¼‚æ˜¯å¦è¡¨ç¤ºä¸¤ä¸ªæ€»ä½“ä¹‹é—´çš„çœŸå®å‡å€¼å·®å¼‚ã€‚ Pooled Variance åˆå¹¶æ–¹å·® Definition å®šä¹‰ Provides an unbiased basis for calculating the standard error. æä¾›è®¡ç®—æ ‡å‡†è¯¯å·®çš„æ— ååŸºç¡€ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$s_p^2 = \frac{SS_1 + SS_2}{df_1 + df_2}$$ Repeated-Measures t Test é‡å¤æµ‹é‡tæ£€éªŒ Definition å®šä¹‰ Evaluate the mean difference between two treatment conditions using data from a single sample. ä½¿ç”¨å•ä¸ªæ ·æœ¬çš„æ•°æ®è¯„ä¼°ä¸¤ä¸ªå¤„ç†æ¡ä»¶ä¹‹é—´çš„å¹³å‡å·®å¼‚ã€‚ Difference Score å·®å¼‚åˆ†æ•°: $$D = X_2 - X_1$$ Confidence Intervals ç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´ Definition å®šä¹‰ Range of values that estimate the unknown population mean. ä¼°è®¡æœªçŸ¥æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼çš„å€¼èŒƒå›´ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$\mu = M \pm t(s_M)$$

posts.title: PSY2043 Ch01 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch01 The Nature of Psychology INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES Understand the scope of scientific psychology. The scope of psychology is broad, covering topics such as face recognition, social judgments, memory, obesity, violence, and many more. Understand differing historical perspectives on the topics within psychology. Know five contemporary perspectives within psychology. Historical perspectives Structralism (the analysis of mental structures) Functionalism (studying how the mind works so that an organism can adapt to and function in its environment) Behaviorism (the study of behavior without reference to consciousness) Gestalt psychology (which focuses on the patterns formed by stimuli and on the organization of experience) Psychoanalysis (which emphasizes the role of unconscious processes in personality development and motivation) Information-processing theory Psycholinguistics Neuropsychology 5 Contemporary perspectives Biological perspectives Behavioral perspectives Cognitive perspectives Psychoanalytic perspectives Subjectivist perspectives Be familiar with seven major subfields within contemporary psychology. Know four cutting-edge interdisciplinary approaches in psychology. 7 Major subfields Biological psychology Cognitive psychology Developmental psychology Social and personality psychology Clincial and counseling psychology School and educational psychology Organizational and engineering psychology 4 Cutting-edge interdisciplinary approaches in psychology Cognitive neuroscience â€“ learn how mental activities are executed in the brain (scanning). Evolutionary psychology â€“ psychological mechanisms have a genetic basis and in the past increased our ancestorsâ€™ chances of surviving and reproducing. Cultural psychology Postive psychology Define psychology. Give examples of psychological research. Psychology can be defined as the scientifc study of behavior and mental process. Examples Brain damage and face recognition Attributing traits to people Childhood amnesia Obesity Effects of media violence on childrenâ€™s aggresion Identify key ideas and debates that shaped the history of psychology. Give examples of five different perspectives within contemporary psychology. idea â€“ mind and behavior could be the subject of scientific analysis â€“ scientific psychology born debate â€“ nature vs nurture Explain how psychologists use the scientific method to uncover knowledge. Generating a hypothesis Testing it by using a scientific method Experimental method Correlational method Observational method State the principles that guide the ethical conduct of psychological research. Minimal risk Informed consent Right to privacy The Scope of Psychology To evaluate new claims made about psychology, you need to know(1) what psychological facts are already firmly established(2) the standards for scientific evidence. Psychology can be defined as the scientifc study of behavior and mental process. The Historical Origins of Psychology Nature-nurture debate Roots of psychology can be traced to the 4th and 5th centuries B.C. One of the earliest debates about human psychology focused on the question of whether human capabilities are inborn or acquired through experience (the natureâ€“nurture debate). The beginnings of scientific psychology ç§‘å­¦å¿ƒç†å­¦ Scientific psychology was born in the late nineteenth century with the idea that mind and behavior could be the subject of scientific analysis. The first experimental laboratory in psychology was established by Wilhelm Wundt at the University of Leipzig in 1879. ï¼ˆåä¹ä¸–çºªæœ« Wilhelm Wundt å»ºç«‹ï¼‰ Wilhelm Wundt: Introspectionï¼ˆå†…çœæ³•ï¼‰- observing and recording the nature of oneâ€™s own perceptions, thoughts, and feelings The early â€˜schoolsâ€™ of psychology in the twentieth century Structuralism and funtionalismï¼ˆç»“æ„ä¸»ä¹‰å’ŒåŠŸèƒ½ä¸»ä¹‰ï¼‰ Titchener â€“ structuralism â€“ the analysis of mental structures William James â€“ functionalism â€“ studying how the mind works to enable an organism to adapt to and function in its environment. Both structuralists and functionalists still regarded psychology as the science of conscious experience Behaviorismï¼ˆè¡Œä¸ºä¸»ä¹‰ï¼‰ Watson, and others ascribing to behaviorism, argued that nearly all behavior is a result of conditioning and the environment shapes behavior by reinforcing specific habits. Gestalt psychologyï¼ˆæ ¼å¼å¡”å¿ƒç†å­¦ï¼‰ The Gestalt psychologistsâ€™ primary interest was perception, and they believed that perceptual experiences depend on the patterns formed by stimuli and on the organization of experience. Psychoanalysisï¼ˆç²¾ç¥åˆ†æï¼‰ At the center of Freudâ€™s theory is the concept of the unconscious â€“ the thoughts attitudes, impulses, wishes, motivations, and emotions of which we are unaware. Later developments in twentieth-century psychology Information-processing theoryï¼ˆä¿¡æ¯å¤„ç†ç†è®ºï¼‰ Psycholinguisticsï¼ˆå¿ƒç†è¯­è¨€å­¦ï¼‰ Neuropsychologyï¼ˆç¥ç»å¿ƒç†å­¦ï¼‰ Contemporary Psychology Perspectives The biological perspective The behaviroal perspective The cognitive perspective The psychoanalytic perspective The subjectivist perspective An orientation toward understanding behavior and mental processes in terms of the subjective realities people actively construct. Relationships between psychological and biological perspectives Reductionism - Biological researchers often attempt to explain psychological principles in terms of biological ones Major subfields of psychology Biological psychology Cognitive psychology Developmental psychology Social and personality psychology Clincial and counseling psychology School and educational psychology Organizational and engineering psychology How Psychological Research is Done Generating hypotheses Experiments Correlation Observation Literature reviews Ethics of psychological

posts.title: PSY2043 Ch02 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch02 Biological Foundations of Psychology INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES Understand the organization and the physiology of the human brain. Have learned the research methods used to study the brain. computerized axial tomography (CT) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) positron emission tomography (PET) Be able to consider evolutionary arguments. Darwin â€“ Nature selection â€“ variations on inheritable traits that most contribute to an organismâ€™s survival that are passed on to the next generation. Explain the basics of the biology of the brain. Identify key areas in the human brain, including their function. Understand key principles concerning the heredity of behavior. An individualâ€™s hereditary potential, which is transmitted by the chromosomes and genes, influences his or her psychological and physical characteristics. The Study of the Biological Bases of Psychology peripheral nervous system å‘¨å›´ç¥ç»ç³»ç»Ÿ spinal cord è„ŠæŸ± afferent nerves ä¼ å…¥ç¥ç» efferent nerves ä¼ å‡ºç¥ç» somatic nervous system èº¯ä½“ç¥ç»ç³»ç»Ÿ autonomic nervous system è‡ªä¸»ç¥ç»ç³»ç»Ÿ Neurons, the Building Block of the Nervous System Neuronsâ€™ three categories Sensory neurons â€“ transmit impulses from receptors to CNS Motor neurons â€“ carry outgoing signals from CNS to muscles and glands Inter-neurons â€“ connect sensory and motor neurons Action potentials 5åˆ†é’Ÿæé€Ÿè®¤è¯†ç¥ç»ç³»ç»Ÿå’Œè„‘ - è‰¾è²çš„æ–‡ç«  - Synaptic transmission and neural codingNeurotransmittersInhibitory neurotransmitters GABA â€“ Major inhibitory neurotransmitter in brain. Drugs that alleviate anxiety enhance activity of GABA. Serotonin â€“ Important in mood and social behavior. Drugs that alleviate depression and anxiety increase serotonin levels in synapse. Excitatory neurotransmitters Acetylcholine â€“ Involved in memory and attention; decreases associated with Alzheimerâ€™s disease. Also transmits signals between nerve and muscle. Norepinephrine â€“ Increased by psycho-timulants. Low levels contribute to depression. Dopamine â€“ Mediates the effects of natural rewards (food and sex, for example) and drugs of abuse. Glutamate â€“ Major excitatory neurotransmitter in brain. Involved in learning and memory. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch06 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch06 Consciousness Intended Learning Outcomes Define consciousness in terms of its function in monitoring information and controlling our actions. Know what is meant by the terms preconscious memories and the unconscious. Be familiar with the phenomena of automaticity and of dissociation. Discuss in some detail sleep schedules, stages of sleep, REM and NREM sleep, and sleep disorders. Describe Freudâ€™s perspective on the purpose of dreams. Define meditation and describe the consequences of meditation training. Know what is meant by the term psychoactive drug. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch07 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch07 Learning and Conditioning Intended Learning Outcomes Understand the history of the study of animal and human learning. Know the different types of conditioning and the way in which they are studied. Understand the brain physiology underlying learning processes. Know the topics of cognition and motivation, as they interact with learning. Identify different types of learning such as: classical versus instrumental conditioning, and observational learning. Explain the empirical paradigms used to study learning processes. Identify situations in which cognitions and/or motivations affect learning. posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch05 Perception Intended Learning Outcomes Describe the role, benefits, and costs of selective attention in perception. benefits â€“ selective attention pares down the amount of necessary information processing to the point where it is manageable by the brain costs â€“ ignoring large parts of the environment, we lose the ability to remember much about those parts of the environment Understand the principles of object separation, distance perception, and motion perception. Feature integration theory ç‰¹å¾æ•´åˆè®º åœ¨å‰æ³¨æ„é˜¶æ®µï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬çš„ç‰¹å¾ï¼ˆprimitive featuresï¼‰ï¼Œè¢«çŸ¥è§‰åˆ° åœ¨æ³¨æ„é˜¶æ®µï¼Œusing attentions to â€œglueâ€ features together ç‰¹å¾æ•´åˆè®ºçš„é—®é¢˜ï¼šç ”ç©¶å‘ç°å¤ªå¤šçš„ â€primitivesâ€œ ï¼ˆåŸå§‹ç‰¹å¾ï¼‰å¹¶ä¸ç°å® æ›¿ä»£ç†è®º - åŠ¨æ€æ§åˆ¶è®ºï¼ˆdynamic control theoryï¼‰ system rearranges itself for different tasks Learn what the difference is between bottom-up and top-down processing. Bottom-up processes â€“ driven solely by the input Top-down processes â€“ driven by personâ€™s knowledge, experience, attention and expectations Learn why abstraction is important. Abstracted information takes less space and is therefore faster to work with than raw information. Explain how the perceptual system achieves and maintains constancy, and how this can cause illusions. illusions â€“ the perceptual systemâ€™s insistence on maintainingconstancies. Briefly describe the neural underpinnings of attention, recognition, and localization. Three separate brain systems The first system is generally associated with arousal. The second, or posterior system, selects objects on the basis of location, shape, or color. The third, or anterior system is responsible for guiding this process, depending on the goals of the viewer. The visual cortex operates according to the principle of division of labor. Localization is mediated by a region near the top of the cortex, and recognition by a region near the bottom of the cortex. Recognition processes are further subdivided into separate modules such as color, shape, and texture. Recognition and localization are carried out by two different regions of the visual cortex. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch15 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch15 Psychological Disorders Intended Learning Outcomes Know the four criteria that may be used in defining abnormality as well as the characteristics that are considered indicative of normality. Abnormality Deviation from cultural norms åç¦»æ–‡åŒ–è§„èŒƒ Deviation from statistical norms åç¦»ç»Ÿè®¡å¸¸æ¨¡ Maladaptive behavior è¡Œä¸ºçš„é€‚åº”æ€§ï¼ˆå¯¹ä¸ªäººæˆ–ç¤¾ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿä¸åˆ©å½±å“ï¼‰ Personal distress ä¸ªäººç—›è‹¦ Nomality Appropriate perception of reality å¯¹ç°å®çš„æ­£ç¡®çŸ¥è§‰ Ability to exercise voluntary control over behavior è‡ªä¸»æ§åˆ¶è¡Œä¸º Self-esteem and acceptance è‡ªå°ŠåŠè‡ªæˆ‘æ¥çº³ Ability to form affectionate relationships å½¢æˆäº²å¯†å…³ç³»çš„èƒ½åŠ› Productivity å…·æœ‰ç”Ÿäº§åŠ› Understand the advantages and disadvantages of classifying abnormal behavior into categories. Advantages Aids diagnosis & treatment Enables quick and concise communication Disadvantages Labeling induces us to overlook unique features of person and expect person to conform to classification doesnâ€™t tell us how the symptoms originated or what causes them to continue stigma in many societies Know the broad perspectives of the biological, psychoanalytic, behavior, cognitive, and sociocultural models. Biological â€“ brain disorders Psychoanalytic â€“ unconscious conflicts Behavior â€“ conditioning and reinforcement & learned fear & learned maladaptive behavior Cognitive â€“ maladaptive cognitive process Sociocultural models â€“ social context Vulnerability-stress model â€“ the interaction between a predisposition that make a person vulnerable to a particular health problem and stressful environmental Describe four types of anxiety disorders. Understand the development of anxiety disorders from the standpoint of biological, cognitive, behavioral, and psychodynamic theories. Know what research on biological factors has contributed thus far to our understanding of these disorders. Anxiety disorders Generalized anxiety (constant worry and tension) Panic disorders (sudden attacks of overwhelming apprehension) Phobias (irrational fears of specific objects or situations) Obsessive-compulsive disorder Describe the two major mood disorders and to compare cognitive-behavior, psychoanalytic, and interpersonal theories of depression. Mood disorders Depressive disorder Bipolar disorder Cognitive theories attribute depression to pessimistic views of the self, the world, and the future and to maladaptive attributional styles. Psychodynamic theories view depression as a reactivation of loss of parental affection in a person who is dependent on external approval and tends to turn anger inward. Interpersonal theories view depression as the result of insecurities about relationships and maladaptive patterns of social interaction. Know the defining characteristics of schizophrenia and be able to give examples of each characteristic. Disturbances of thought and attention loosening of associations â€“ word salad delusion Disturbances of perception hallucinations Disturbances of emotional expression express emotions that are inappropriately linked to the situation or to the thought being expressed, such as smiling while speaking of tragic events. Be familiar with the research on the causes of schizophrenia; be able to discuss the probable contributions of genetic, biochemical, and psychological factors. Genetic â€“ Schizophrenia clearly is transmitted genetically Biochemical â€“ have problems in dopamine regulation Psychological â€“ Psychosocial factors play important role in overall severity & triggering of new episodes Define personality disorders; know the defining characteristics and probable causes of antisocial personalities and borderline personality disorder. Definition â€“ long-standing patterns of maladaptive behavior involving difficulties in coping with stress or solving problems ASPD Biological factors Genetic factors play a role in development of antisocial personality â€“ twin studies confirm genetic component Deficits in executive functions could lead to poor impulse control & difficulty in anticipating consequences Social factors Neglectful & hostile parents may contribute to disorder Personality factors Children with antisocial personalities process information about social interactions in ways that promote aggressive reactions BPD Psychoanalytic theorists argue poorly developed views of self & others stem from poor early relationships with caregivers Others argue deficit in ability to regulate emotions Understand the patterns of behavior that constitute autism spectrum disorders. Describe the biological causes of autism spectrum disorders. Diagnose â€“ three types of deficits Social interaction â€“ lack of connection with others Communication â€“ difficulties in communication & speech Activities & interests â€“ preoccupation/routines/rituals Biological causes Genetics Neurological factors â€“ disruption in normal development & organization of the brain DEFINING ABNORMALITY å˜æ€çš„å®šä¹‰Deviation from cultural norms åç¦»æ–‡åŒ–è§„èŒƒDeviation from statistical norms åç¦»ç»Ÿè®¡å¸¸æ¨¡Maladaptive behavior é€‚åº”ä¸è‰¯çš„è¡Œä¸ºï¼ˆå¯¹ä¸ªäººæˆ–ç¤¾ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿä¸åˆ©å½±å“ï¼‰Personal distress ä¸ªäººç—›è‹¦ Individualâ€™s subjective feelings of distress e.g. anxiety, depression, or agitation çƒ¦èº, or insomnia å¤±çœ , loss of appetite or numerous pains and aches Maybe the only symptom to determin disorder What is normality? å¯¹ç°å®çš„æœ‰æ•ˆçŸ¥è§‰ è‡ªä¸»æ§åˆ¶è¡Œä¸ºçš„èƒ½åŠ› è‡ªå°ŠåŠæ¥çº³ å½¢æˆäº²å¯†å…³ç³»çš„èƒ½åŠ› å…·æœ‰ç”Ÿäº§åŠ› Classifying mental health problems Advantages Aids diagnosis & treatment Enables quick and concise communication Disadvantages Labeling induces us to overlook unique features of person and expect person to conform to classification doesnâ€™t tell us how the symptoms originated or what causes them to continue stigma in many societies Perspectives on mental health problems Biological perspectives â€“ due to brain disorders Psychological perspective â€“ posts.title: PSY2043 Ch16 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch16 Treatment of Mental Health Problems Intended Learning Outcomes Be familiar with the historical background and current trends in the treatment of abnormal behavior, in particular deinstitutionalization and reinstitutionalization. Deinstitutionalization 1960s movement of patients from hospitals to community-based servicesx Be able to describe the following approaches to psychotherapy, including the therapistâ€™s techniques and the patientâ€™s or clientâ€™s experiences that are presumed to yield improvement: Psychoanalysis and psychodynamic therapies; Behavior therapies; Cognitive-behavior therapies; Humanistic therapies; Family and marital therapies. Psychoanalysis and psychodynamic therapies Techniques: free association, dream analysis, transference. Behavior therapies Learning & conditioning Systematic desensitization In vivo exposure Selective reinforcement Modelling Behavioral rehearsal Self-regulation Cognitive-behavior therapies Humanistic therapies Client-centred therapy Family and marital therapies Be familiar with the techniques, advantages, and disadvantages of the two forms of biological therapy; be able to describe the major classes of psychotherapeutic drugs, their effects, and their applications to mental disorders. Electroconvulsive therapy Advantage â€“ Subject of controversy but effective in bringing some out of severe depression faster than drug therapy Disadvantage â€“ Can cause permanent memory loss and confusion Drug therapy Antipsychotic drugs â€“ alter levels of the dopamine â€“ schizophrenia Antidepressant drugs â€“ affecting levels of the neurotransmitters serotonin and norepinephrine â€“ Lithium â€“ Regulates levels of serotonin, norepinephrine, and other neurotransmitters â€“ bipolar disorders Antianxiety drugs â€“ Depresses central nervous system Stimulants â€“ Increasing levels of dopamine Be familiar with the suggestions offered for promoting your own emotional well-being. Accept your feelings Know your vulnerabilities Develop your talents and interests Become involved with other people Know when to seek help HISTORICAL BACKGROUND Earliest belief â€“ demon-possessed é¬¼é™„èº« å¤ä¸­å›½ï¼šé˜´é˜³å¤±è¡¡ Hippocratesï¼šdisturbance in body fluids ä½“æ¶²ç´Šä¹± Middle agesï¼šdemon-possessed Early asylums 1792 Philippe Pinel Morden treatment facilitiesProfessionals who provide psychotherapyTECHNIQUES OF PSYCHOTHERAPYBehavior therapies è¡Œä¸ºç–—æ³• ä»¥å­¦ä¹ åŠæ¡ä»¶ä½œç”¨åŸåˆ™ä¸ºåŸºç¡€æ‰€å‘å±•çš„æ²»ç–—æ–¹æ³• Systematic desensitization ç³»ç»Ÿè„±æ•æ³• In vivo exposure å®æ™¯æš´éœ²æ³• Flooding Selective reinforcement Modeling æ¨¡ä»¿ è§‚å¯Ÿä¸€ä½æ²»ç–—å¸ˆæ¡ç€ä¸€åªè›‡ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å‡è½»æƒ§è›‡è€…å¯¹è›‡çš„ææƒ§ Behavioral rehearsal è¡Œä¸ºæ¼”ç»ƒ æ²»ç–—å¸ˆå¸®åŠ©æ‚£è€…é¢„æ¼”æˆ–ç»ƒä¹ æ›´é€‚å½“çš„è¡Œä¸º Self-regulation Cognitive-behavior therapies è®¤çŸ¥è¡Œä¸ºç–—æ³•Treatment methods that use behavior modification techniques but also incorporate procedures designed to change maladaptive beliefs. Psychodynamic therapies å¿ƒç†åŠ¨åŠ›å­¦ç–—æ³• Traditional psychoanalysis Through free association, dream analysis, and transference, attempts to discover the unconscious basis of the clientâ€™s current problems so as to deal with them in a more rational way. Contemporary psychodynamic therapies (e.g., interpersonal therapy) More structured and short-term than traditional psychoanalysis; emphasize the way the client is currently interacting with others.
